text: Michael you have a fascinating story
about the kind of stress that people are
under who get laid off and the long-term
effects on their health give us a sense
of how much of a trauma is it for
someone who's laid off right I mean when
you think about job loss when you talk
to people about it they they compare it
to other psychological trauma like
losing a family member and and so it is
a major stressor and there are studies a
growing body of research that connects
it to serious health problems heart
attacks strokes
you know diabetes psychological problems
all kinds of stress-related issues on
the one hand it does seem intuitive that
being laid off would be a stressful
thing on the other hand what is it about
being laid off exactly that affects
people's health right so this is one of
the really interesting areas of study
that they really require more research
on they're focusing though on sort of
the direct and indirect fallout from
stress so direct result could be you
know there are certain biochemical
things that have it inside your body
when you go through a stressful event
that could trigger like a heart attack
but then there's also sort of these
indirect things like stress causes
people change their habits so people
could smoke more people could drink more
people then there are studies that tie
for example smoking to job loss and and
other physical habits that could affect
your health and so they're looking at
those areas there's also obviously the
effect of loss of income and what does
that do to for example your access to
health insurance and good health care
and all these other things that you need
to maintain your health is there is
there any thing any advice for people
who are laid off you know ways that they
might try to offset some of these these
effects and try to keep their health
maintained at some even level I mean is
there some tricks that people can learn
well I mean I don't get into that
necessarily in the store
I mean I guess it's kind of obvious that
you need to pay attention to this I mean
the heart of the story is about these
steel workers who lost their jobs up in
Buffalo and several of them had heart
attacks and two of them were fatal and
if the thought really didn't cross their
minds I mean I talked to one guy who who
survived and and and when he was having
the heart attack he thought he had
pulled a muscle in his chest and and and
and he was 42 years old and he didn't
think that this could be happening
unfortunately I mean they caught it and
and he survived but you just have to
watch these things and and you know I
intend to know what you're feeling okay
exactly and I mean and also probably you
you you should watch out for certain
habits like you know you know the but in
two of the cases they're surviving
relatives told me that they had been
drinking more and smoking more and those
are things that you need to watch after
as you're going through the trauma of
unemployment
